Mathematics is a peculiar sort kind of language. Students seeking tutoring in mathematics often have difficulty understanding how to engage with math language. Often times they are engaging with math language as if it is done best by properly memorizing and following the instructions in an instruction booklet. This strategy of engagement fails to produce good results. The student then develops anxiety and a sense that the instructions are â€œtricky.â€ Often there develops a sense of being oppressed by mathematics. It can be difficult to recognize that it is actually the strategy of interpretation that is not working.

Things may get even more difficult when a student seeks out help from teachers or tutors. That is because many math instructors are â€œmath people.â€ Math people do not always know why they themselves are good at math
column2: so they tell students to just do what they do. This leads to more â€œinstruction manualâ€ type learning
column3: which is counter-productive. Math people often do not know how to recognize the interpretive underpinnings of mathematics. They haven't thought much about it
column4: since math has always worked for them. When the math people try to help a confused or anxious student
column5: they may inadvertently make things worse by amplifying the sense that the student is doing it â€œwrong.â€

column1: The curious thing about my experience in tutoring math is that the student is never just doing it wrong. Resistance to mathematics is a meaningful expression that can be interpreted by a person who is able to listen and comprehend in a responsive way. When a student is relieved of the pressure of not knowing how to do math â€œright
column2: â€ the resistances become shared and meaningful
column3: and this leads to transformative learning. In time
column4: I commonly end up talking to my students about deeper issues like
column5: â€œwhat is a number?â€ Little by little
column6: students are able to let go of their resistances and become independent learners in mathematics. Mathematics becomes a vehicle to teach students freedom of thought
column8: greater mental maturity. I typically work with students in middle school
column10: but I am happy to work with any age or level. I use sliding scale rates
column11: $40-$80/hour depending on number of lessons and your financial circumstances. I will come to your location. I am willing to travel in a 20 mile radius from Pinole. I am vaccinated and boosted.
